items.translated_title: Sanctioned spyware maker Intellexa had direct access to government espionage victims, researchers say
items.content: Based on a leaked video, security researchers alleged that Intellexa staffers have remote live access to their customers' surveillance systems, allowing them to see hacking targets’ personal data.

items.translated_title: Amazon’s new Kindle Scribe and Kindle Scribe Colorsoft launch on December 10
items.content: The new Kindle Scribe has a larger 11-inch glare-free display, is just 5.4 mm thick, and weighs only 400 g. It’s also 40% faster when writing or turning pages.

items.translated_title: California’s ban on self-driving trucks could soon be over
items.content: Revised rules in California would allow self-driving trucks to test on public highways. The rules also close a loophole allowing police to issue tickets for driverless vehicles.

items.translated_title: Why Day One Ventures’ Masha Bucher thinks VCs and storytelling go hand-in-hand
items.content: Day One Ventures' Masha Bucher doesn't just invest in startups — she also tells their stories. Her integrated model aligns incentives and proves conviction matters more than contracts.

items.translated_title: Amazon reportedly considering dropping USPS and building a competing postal service

items.translated_title: EU investigating Meta over policy change that bans rival AI chatbots from WhatsApp

items.creator: Aisha Malik

items.translated_title: Gemini was Google’s top trending search term in 2025
items.content: Every year, Google releases a report highlighting the top trending searches, offering a snapshot of what captured our collective curiosity, spanning pop culture, entertainment, internet trends, and news events. Gemini wasn’t the only AI chatbot to make the list, as DeepSeek ranked seventh among the year’s trending searches.

items.translated_title: New unicorn Brevo raises $583M to challenge CRM giants
items.content: Brevo, a customer relationship management company headquartered in Paris, is now a unicorn. The U.S. currently represents 15% of Brevo’s revenue — one of its three largest markets along with France and Germany.
